In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is how you can do this in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(d::Date)
    error("This function only works with DateTime types, not Date types.")
end
```
In this code, we define two versions of the `timezone_bumper` function. The first version accepts a DateTime type and returns a new DateTime object that is `bump` hours ahead of the input date-time. The second version accepts a Date type and throws an error message. This way, if you pass in a Date, it will throw an error, but if you pass in a DateTime, it will work as expected.
